mil3.1.10:0.3: Calming as a Distinguishing Characteristic of Faith Question
mil3.1.10:1.2: “Venerable Nāgasena, what is the distinguishing characteristic of faith?”
mil3.1.10:1.3: “Faith, your majesty, has calming as a distinguishing characteristic, and also aspiration.”
mil3.1.10:1.4: “How, venerable sir, is calming a distinguishing characteristic of faith?”
mil3.1.10:1.5: “Faith suppresses the hindrances that are arising, and thus there is a clear, bright, clean mind free of the hindrances.
mil3.1.10:1.6: That’s how, your majesty, calming is the distinguishing characteristic of faith.”
mil3.1.10:2.2: “Just as, your majesty, a wheel-turning king going on a long journey might cross a small stream, and that water disturbed by the elephants, horses, chariots, and foot-soldiers, would become stirred up, turbid, and muddy;
mil3.1.10:2.3: and after crossing, the king would command his men, ‘Bring me water, I will drink,’ and the king would have a water-clearing gem.
mil3.1.10:2.4: And the men having given their assent to the wheel-turning king, saying ‘Yes, lord’, would place that water-clearing gem in the water, and after it is placed in that water, the various water plants would disappear, the mud would settle, and water would become clear, bright, and clean.
mil3.1.10:2.5: Then they would bring the water to the wheel-turning king, saying, ‘Drink the water, lord.’
mil3.1.10:3.1: Just like the water, your majesty, so the mind is to be understood; like the men, so the spiritual aspirant is to be understood; like the various water plants and the mud, so the defilements are to be understood;
